awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Collaborative Research: Interactions of Polishing and Incidental Nanoparticles in Chemical Mechanical Planarization Processes with Artificial Membranes and Human Cell Lines
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Chen, Kai Loon
#: 1605815
COLLABORATIVE
PI: Aravamudhan, Shyam  
#: 1604647

Chemical Mechanical Planarization (CMP) is one of the important semiconductor manufacturing processes used in the production of advanced electronic devices such as computers, smart phones, and tablets. The CMP process uses huge volumes (millions of tons) of silica, ceria, or alumina particles in the form of abrasive slurries to planarize electronic circuits during the manufacturing process. However, environmental safety and health (ESH) impacts from the release of used CMP slurries containing nanoparticles into the natural environment and workplace exposure are largely unknown. The objective of this research is to study the ESH impacts and interactions of both pristine and used CMP nanoparticles with artificial cell membranes and human cell lines.

Even though NPs are used in a large-scale in the CMP process during the manufacture of integrated circuits, little is known about their environmental and human health impacts, particularly the transformation of nanoparticles during the CMP process and their corresponding workplace exposure, fate, behavior, and toxicity. This is mainly due to the inability to obtain access to the transformed nanoparticle slurries from the CMP process. The main objectives of this project are to (1) systematically investigate, detect, and characterize the transformation of nanoparticle slurries during the CMP processes; (2) examine the influence of CMP and incidental nanoparticles to attach to and disrupt artificial cell membranes and their ability to affect human cell lines; and (3) determine the role of nanoparticle-membrane interactions on nanoparticle toxicity.

This research has the potential to be transformative because a strong understanding of the biological interactions of pristine and transformed CMP NPs is not only relevant to the electronics industry, but also has wider applicability for a number of other nanoparticle applications, which routinely undergo life-cycle transformations through different physical and chemical processes. The research results will be disseminated through publications in peer-reviewed journals and student presentations at national scientific meetings. They will also be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate courses and community outreach programs, including K-12 scientific activities for an inner-city Baltimore elementary/middle school, NanoDay activities for the local community, NanoBus after-school program, and community college engagement. Lastly, the active involvement of an industrial partner will result in implementation of better engineering controls and safer CMP processes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Background

Nanomaterials and nanoparticles are increasingly exploited for their novel properties in engineering applications, yet the impact of these materials on human and environmental health is relatively poorly characterized. Nanoparticles are typically defined as material that is less than 100-500 nanometers in size. These particles have many characteristics that can be exploited for engineering and manufacturing applications, such antibacterial, magnetic, and catalytic functionality. Because of this functionality, over 1000 kg of engineered nanomaterials are produced annually, for use in medicinal, electronic, industrial, and environmental applications. Because many nanoparticles cause cellular toxicity, more work is needed to evaluate the potential impact of these materials on human and environmental health, especially associated with nanoparticle release into the environment through manufacturing waste streams.

Nanoparticles are commonly used in semiconductor fabrication to polish the wafer base of integrated circuits, the small chips used in common electronics, in a process called chemical mechanical planarization (CMP). The resulting planarized surfaces are required for the proper placement of hundreds of millions of transistors that make up integrated circuit devices. While crucial to the $325.4 billion semiconductor industry, CMP is in itself an industry valued at over $1.5 billion annually. The process of polishing typically includes silica, ceria, and alumina nanoparticles, generally in the size range of 2-200 nm. CMP wastewater treatment is site-specific and releases unknown concentrations of silica, ceria, and alumina nanoparticles into surface waters. These nanoparticles experience strong mechanical forces and are exposed to a range of chemical additives, which could alter the physical or chemical characteristics of the nanoparticles, influencing their toxicity and increasing the risk to human or environmental health upon exposure to this waste.

Because characteristics of nanoparticles could be altered during the manufacturing process and the toxicity of nanoparticles used in electronics manufacturing are poorly characterized, we sought to characterize the physical and chemical characteristics of nanoparticles before and after use in CMP. Additionally, we investigated how nanoparticles before and after CMP interact with model cell membranes and whether they attach to or interfere with the growth of microorganisms. These investigations are needed to ensure that waste released into the environment after electronics manufacturing does not pose a significant risk to human or environmental health.

Results

CMP nanoparticles were characterized to determine physicochemical changes incurred during CMP processing that may alter their environmental fate and cytotoxicity. No significant changes in size, charge, or aggregation behaviors were observed. Interactions of CMP nanoparticles with model cell membranes were assessed using Quartz Crystal Microbalance with Dissipation Monitoring (QCM-D). Ceria and alumina nanoparticles did not interact strongly with model cell membranes, likely due to stabilizing slurry additives that remained effective even at high dilutions. Silica nanoparticles showed the strongest tendency to attach to supported lipid bilayers, with significant attachment detected at concentrations as low as 1 mg/L, which increased with salinity. Release of dye from supported lipid bilayer vesicles was not detected, suggesting that attachment did not result in substantial membrane rupture. Attachment was correlated with epithelial cell membrane damage observed by collaborators at North Carolina A&T State University. However, no significant toxicity or attachment to microbial cells (Cyanobacteria) could be detected at any silica nanoparticle concentration or salinity measured.

Implications of our work

This works suggests that the nanoparticles used in CMP during electronics manufacturing pose a minimal risk to human or environmental health either before or after use in the manufacturing process. While exposure of human cells to silica nanoparticles was associated with toxicity, other nanoparticles did not cause substantial toxicity and other cell types (i.e. microorganisms) did not experience toxicity or substantial attachment when present in growth media. While the possibility of unobserved health or environmental risks cannot be ruled out, this work demonstrates that CMP nanoparticles are not substantially altered during the CMP process and release of these nanoparticles into the environment is not likely to be associated with significant environmental risks.

 

Broader Impacts

This work tests whether nanoparticle waste generated during electronics manufacturing is likely to pose an increased risk to human or environmental health. Women are typically underrepresented in engineering disciplines, and this award supported the training, professional development and research activities of a woman PhD student in Environmental Engineering.

 


Last Modified: 11/23/2021
Modified by: Sarah Preheim
